chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Contraindications and cautions of pregabalin
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Prescribe pregabalin with caution to people:

  • With renal impairment — a reduced initial and maximum daily dosage is recommended. For more information, see the section on dose and titration.
  • At risk of encephalopathy — cases of encephalopathy have been reported, mostly in people with underlying conditions that may precipitate the condition.
  • With diabetes — pregabalin may cause weight gain. People with diabetes who gain weight on pregabalin may need to adjust their anti-diabetic medication.
  • At risk of falls (such as older people) — pregabalin has been associated with dizziness and somnolence, and there have been post-marketing reports of loss of consciousness, confusion, and mental impairment.
  • At risk of cardiovascular compromise — due to the risk of congestive heart failure. Discontinue if the person develops symptoms of heart failure (such as breathlessness, fatigue, and ankle swelling) or worsening of heart failure.
  • At risk of suicide — there is a small increased risk of suicidal ideation and behaviour in people treated with antiepileptic drugs. The mechanism of this risk is not known and the available data do not exclude the possibility of an increased risk for pregabalin.
    • Monitor at-risk people for signs of suicidal ideation.
  • Using medications that can cause constipation (such as opioids) — there are post-marketing reports of events related to reduced lower gastrointestinal tract function (such as intestinal obstruction, paralytic ileus, and constipation) when pregabalin was co-administered with such medications. 
    • During combination therapy, measures to prevent constipation should be considered, especially in women and older people.

[ABPI, 2017f; BNF 73, 2017]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the adverse effects of pregabalin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Adverse effects of pregabalin include:

  • CNS effects — such as dizziness, somnolence, headache, ataxia, abnormal coordination, tremor, dysarthria, amnesia, memory impairment, inattention, paraesthesia, hypoaesthesia, sedation, balance disorder, lethargy.
  • Increased appetite and weight gain. 
  • Psychiatric effects — such as euphoria, confusion, irritability, disorientation, insomnia, suicidal thoughts and behaviour.
  • Sexual dysfunction — such as decreased libido, erectile dysfunction.
  • Gastrointestinal effects — such as vomiting, nausea, constipation, diarrhoea, flatulence, abdominal distension, dry mouth.
  • Ocular effects — such as blurred vision and diplopia.
  • Musculoskeletal and connective tissue effects — such as muscle cramp, arthralgia, back pain, limb pain, cervical spasm.
  • Respiratory effects — severe respiratory depression.

[ABPI, 2017f; BNF 73, 2017; ABPI, 2020c]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the key drug interactions with pregabalin?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Pregabalin has no clinically important pharmacokinetic drug interactions. However:
    • There may be additive sedative effects if pregabalin is used with other central nervous system depressants (such as alcohol and benzodiazepines).
    • Pregabalin used alongside opioid analgesics may cause reduced lower gastrointestinal tract function, leading to intestinal obstruction, paralytic ileus, and/or constipation.

[ABPI, 2017f]

subChapters.htmlHeader: What dose of pregabalin should I prescribe and how should I titrate the dose?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Start treatment at 150 mg daily (in two to three divided doses). If required, increase in steps of 150 mg daily at seven-day intervals. Maximum dose 600 mg daily in two to three divided doses.
  • A lower starting dose may be appropriate for people with reduced renal function. Please see table 1 for further details.
  • Seek specialist advice and consult the manufacturer's Summary of Product Characteristics for people undergoing haemodialysis.
